 </li></div><div><li>3. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#3">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Today’s </a> Speakers
ADAM MEYERS |
VP, INTELLIGENCE
Recognized speaker, trainer, and intelligence expert with 15+ years
of cyber security industry experience
10 years in the DIB supporting US GOV customers on topics
ranging from wireless, pen testing, IR, and malware analysis

@ADAM_CYBER

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

3

 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#4">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Today’s </a> Speakers
MATT DAHL |
SENIOR ANALYST/ LEGAL COUNSEL
Cyber threat analyst focused on targeted intrusion activity
Focused on investigating indicators of compromise to identify
specific adversary activity
Legal liaison to the CrowdStrike Intelligence Team

@CROWDSTRIKE

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

4

 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#5">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries </a> are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

5

 </li></div><div><li>6. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#6">INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY

Adversary </a> Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

CATEGORIZATION

Timeline: </a> CORSAIR JACKAL

2012 XTnR3v0LT
colludes with Anonymous
group XL3gi0n

January 25, 2013 New
members added

January 22, 2013
XTnR3v0LT announce
formation of TCA

March 1 2013 Announced
compromise of US financial

February 2013
Announced
participation in
#opblacksummer

July 29 2013 Ben Khlifa
announces new personal page

May 7, 2013
XTnR3v0LT
arrested by Tunisian
Authorities

September 2, 2013
Tweets XSS
vulnerability on
Sourceforge

2013 CrowdStrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

WHO IS
CORSAIR
JACKAL?

Primarily One Individual: Fahmi Ben
Khlifa (XTnR3v0LT)
Professed nationalistic motivations for
malicious activity, but also white hat
activity.
Cross-site scripting attacks used to
compromise databases at target
organizations.

 </li></div><div><li>30. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#30">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

30

 </li></div><div><li>31. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#31">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Who's Targeting You and Why? \r\n \r\nNation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:\r\n\r\n    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure \r\n    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft \r\n    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers\r\n    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat It was developed by Lockheed Martin based on military doctrine to measure the effectiveness of defense strategies. Each phase of the kill chain can be mapped to corresponding defensive tools and actions, and understanding what phase an attack is in helps determine an appropriate response. Tracking similarities in tactics across phases can provide insights into threat actors and campaigns. The goal is to disrupt attacks as early in the kill chain as possible to improve security.","tags":["cyber","information security"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/crash1980/cyber-kill-chain-deck-for-general-audience","userLogin":"crash1980","userName":"Tom K","viewCount":388},{"algorithmId":"5","displayTitle":"cyber security","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":19,"score":0.611342,"slideshowId":"179962114","sourceName":"cm_interact","strippedTitle":"cyber-security-179962114","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/jb7ptmsqq86zll6ryfox-signature-32b18edccca4e80820864f52d5649bc5473e7c3a4a3f494541b454bc006b1e26-poli-191008053048-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"The document discusses cyber security. This session will explore how a threat hunting team uses MITRE ATT\u0026CK to understand and categorize adversary activity. ATT\u0026CKcon 4.0\n\nBy Marina Liang\n\n\"LABYRINTH CHOLLIMA is a prolific Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) nexus adversary focused on cyber espionage. They have been recently observed targeting FinTech (financial technology) companies in cryptocurrency revenue generation efforts. LABYRINTH CHOLLIMA has been associated with many high profile attacks, including the Sony Pictures Entertainment (SPE) breach, the WannaCry 2.0 global surge, and most recently, the 3CX supply chain compromise. By shifting to observations of behavior over one-to-one direct alerts, noisy datasets become valuable treasure troves with ATT\u0026CK metadata. Additionally, we can begin to look at detection and threat hunting on behavior instead of users or systems. Key points include:\n\n- The malware uses inline code obfuscation and encrypted strings to hide its functionality and communication domains. Researchers were able to deobfuscate the code and decrypt the strings to analyze the malware. \n\n- Clues in decrypted strings suggest the malware author is Romani, including references to Romani singers in template strings. \n\n- The malware generates domain names by concatenating two randomly selected words from a dictionary and appending \".net\". This allows it to generate many domain variations to communicate with its command and control servers.\n\n- The DGA algorithm uses a 15-bit seed value derived from the","tags":["crowdstrike","cyber","black hat"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/endtoend-analysis-of-a-domain-generating/25244628","userLogin":"CrowdStrike","userName":"CrowdStrike","viewCount":9335},{"algorithmId":"","displayTitle":"TOR... ALL THE THINGS","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":32,"score":0,"slideshowId":"25244568","sourceName":"MORE_FROM_USER","strippedTitle":"tor-all-the-things","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/tor-130814102922-phpapp02-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"The global Tor network and its routing protocols provide an excellent framework for online anonymity. However, the selection of Tor-friendly software for Windows is sub-par at best. \r\n\r\nWant to anonymously browse the web? You’re stuck with Firefox, and don’t even think about trying to anonymously use Flash. Want to dynamically analyze malware without letting the C2 server know your home IP address? You’re outta luck. Want to anonymously use any program that doesn’t natively support SOCKS or HTTP proxying? Not gonna happen. \r\n\r\nWhile some solutions currently exist for generically rerouting traffic through Tor, these solutions either don’t support Windows, or can be circumvented by malware, or require an additional network gateway device. \r\n\r\nMissed the live session at Black Hat USA 2013? Check out the slides from Jason Geffner's standing room only presentation! Jason released a free new CrowdStrike community tool to securely, anonymously, and transparently route all TCP/IP and DNS traffic through Tor, regardless of the client software, and without relying on VPNs or additional hardware or virtual machines.","tags":["crowdstrike","tor","tcp/ip"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things/25244568","userLogin":"CrowdStrike","userName":"CrowdStrike","viewCount":8098},{"algorithmId":"","displayTitle":"End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family Whitepaper","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":41,"score":0,"slideshowId":"25207649","sourceName":"MORE_FROM_USER","strippedTitle":"end-toend-analysis-of-a-domain-generating-algorithm-malware-family-whitepaper","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/end-to-end-20analysis-20of-20a-20domain-20generating-20algorithm-20malware-20family-20-20whitepaper-130813094833-phpapp01-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"The document provides an overview of domain generating algorithms (DGAs) used by malware to dynamically determine remote server addresses and evade detection. While vector databases have traditionally dominated RAG applications, graph databases, specifically knowledge graphs, offer a transformative approach to contextual AI that’s often overlooked. This approach provides unique advantages for applications requiring deep insights, intelligent search, and reasoning over both structured and unstructured sources, making it ideal for complex business scenarios.\n\nAttendees will leave with an understanding of how to build a RAG system using a graph database and practical skills for data querying and insights retrieval. By comparing graph and vector database approaches, we’ll highlight when and why graph databases may offer superior benefits for managing complex data relationships. The session will provide concrete examples and advanced techniques, empowering participants to incorporate knowledge graphs into their AI systems for better data-driven outcomes and improved LLM performance. This discussion will conclude with a live demo showcasing key techniques and insights covered in this talk.\n\nFind more info about All Things Open:\nOn the web: https://www.allthingsopen.org/\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/AllThingsOpen\nLinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/all-things-open/\nInstagram: https://www.instagram.com/allthingsopen/\nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/AllThingsOpen\nMastodon: https://mastodon.social/@allthingsopen\nThreads: https://www.threads.net/@allthingsopen\nBluesky: https://bsky.app/profile/allthingsopen.bsky.social\n2025 conference: https://2025.allthingsopen.org/","tags":["all things open","all things open ai","atoai"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/leveraging-knowledge-graphs-for-rag-a-smarter-approach-to-contextual-ai-applications-david-vonthenen-digitalocean/277168677","userLogin":"AllThingsOpen","userName":"All Things Open","viewCount":25}]},"slideDimensions":{"height":540,"width":959},"sectionSummaries":[{"summaryList":"[\n    {\n        \"slides\": [\n            1,\n            2\n        ],\n        \"topic\": \"Understanding Adversary Problems\",\n        \"cover\": \"Introduction to adversary problems in cybersecurity.
